update.description:
I needed a mechanism to add performers during a simulation run (after load). Spawned models are likely to be performers.

Requires #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/107

## Testing

1. `ign gazebo levels_no_performers.sdf -v 4 --levels`
2. `ign service -s /world/levels/level/set_performer --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 2000 --req 'data: "vehicle_blue"'`
3. ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_blue/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 4.0}"
update.title: [Blueprint] Service to add performers at runtime

pull_request.title: [Blueprint] Service to add performers at runtime

pullrequest.title: [Blueprint] Service to add performers at runtime

content.raw:
I don't believe even read only operations on `EntityComponentManager` are thread safe. Other threads might be modifying containers holding entities or components or updating views inside the ECM when this thread is calling the accessor function. 

Also, there's a data race on `performerMap` and `performersToAdd`. They are modified/read here and in `CreatePerformerEntity`.
content.html:
I don't believe even read only operations on EntityComponentManager are thread safe. Other threads might be modifying containers holding entities or components or updating views inside the ECM when this thread is calling the accessor function.

Also, there's a data race on performerMap and performersToAdd. They are modified/read here and in CreatePerformerEntity.

content.raw:
Right now I'm fine with failing to create a performer if the model has not yet been spawned. 

My understanding of service calls was to return true if the service call executed, and use the response message to pass back information about whether the service call was successful. In this case, the boolean response will be false.
content.html:
Right now I'm fine with failing to create a performer if the model has not yet been spawned.

My understanding of service calls was to return true if the service call executed, and use the response message to pass back information about whether the service call was successful. In this case, the boolean response will be false.

pull_request.title: [Blueprint] Service to add performers at runtime

pullrequest.title: [Blueprint] Service to add performers at runtime

content.raw: The `return` is true, indicating that the service call executed. However the boolean response is false, indicating that the request failed.
content.html: The return is true, indicating that the service call executed. However the boolean response is false, indicating that the request failed.

content.raw: Not sure if this case should return true. I can imagine a user trying to spawn two performers for different models but forgetting to give them different names.

pull_request.title: [Blueprint] Service to add performers at runtime

pullrequest.title: [Blueprint] Service to add performers at runtime

content.raw:
> If I (as a user) wanted to set a new performer via this service, then I would expect to know immediately if the operation was successful or not. I can always call the service again.

Ok, I see. I thought the intention was to prevent a race condition when the performer is set just before the model is spawned.

In any case, true is being returned even though we're not sure that the performer has been added.

> I think an "action" would be more appropriate if we wanted to wait for the model to be spawned.

One thing I'm experimenting with on the state service is actually [blocking on the service callback](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/677d02b99e6b8a17ec2ef427b601a3437afba1b8/src/systems/scene_broadcaster/SceneBroadcaster.cc#lines-407) until the service is successful. This shouldn't block anything else besides that transport thread, and we can return true to the user only when the performer has really been set.
content.html:
If I (as a user) wanted to set a new performer via this service, then I would expect to know immediately if the operation was successful or not. I can always call the service again.

Ok, I see. I thought the intention was to prevent a race condition when the performer is set just before the model is spawned.

In any case, true is being returned even though we're not sure that the performer has been added.

I think an "action" would be more appropriate if we wanted to wait for the model to be spawned.

One thing I'm experimenting with on the state service is actually blocking on the service callback until the service is successful. This shouldn't block anything else besides that transport thread, and we can return true to the user only when the performer has really been set.

pull_request.title: [Blueprint] Service to add performers at runtime

pullrequest.title: [Blueprint] Service to add performers at runtime

content.raw: This only uses an acessor of EntityComponentManager. Is that also not thread safe?
content.html: This only uses an acessor of EntityComponentManager. Is that also not thread safe?

pull_request.title: [Blueprint] Service to add performers at runtime

pullrequest.title: [Blueprint] Service to add performers at runtime

content.raw:
I think the difference is that this is in a service callback that will be executed after simulation has started.

If I (as a user) wanted to set a new performer via this service, then I would expect to know immediately if the operation was successful or not. I can always call the service again.

I think an "action" would be more appropriate if we wanted to wait for the model to be spawned.
content.html:
I think the difference is that this is in a service callback that will be executed after simulation has started.

If I (as a user) wanted to set a new performer via this service, then I would expect to know immediately if the operation was successful or not. I can always call the service again.

I think an "action" would be more appropriate if we wanted to wait for the model to be spawned.
